stream_context.summary: Kaze tests streaming on YouTube while working on 'Return to Yoshi's Island.' The main focus is implementing and refining tutorial bunnies in Course 1, which involves coding their behavior, designing UI prompts with feedback from Biobak, and creating particle-based rings for players to complete challenges.

development_findings.summary: The team is implementing tutorial bunnies in Course 1 to teach players advanced moves like the dive jump and spin jump.
The design for tutorials evolved from a simple 'jump to a coin' challenge to requiring the player to perform a specific move through a particle-based ring, ensuring the intended skill is learned.
development_findings.quote: it kinda defeats the purpose of showcasing the player how useful the jump can be.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has implemented specific engine optimizations, such as organizing code into 'Icache blocks' to ensure related functions (like rendering) fit into the N64's instruction cache for better performance.
development_findings.quote: I called it Icache blocks, where I have a block of code that's always 0x400 bytes, right? So if you look at my map file here... I made sure that all the rendering functions are within the same block of code here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong design principle against taking camera control away from the player unexpectedly. He had to break this rule and hard-code a camera position for the tutorial cutscenes, a solution he described as 'dirty'.
development_findings.quote: if you make the camera rotate without the player being able to predict it, you're always gonna have to play a whole direction that they don't intend... That's why we never actually have the camera do anything without the player somehow forcing that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze estimates the project is around 70% complete, with most of the major engine upgrades finished.
The design for the tutorial rings was inspired by the sparkle rings from Yoshi's Island, and Kaze implemented them using his particle system.
Kaze is replacing the 100-coin stars with a system of five purple coins in each level that grant a star upon collection.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes romhacks have a smaller 'patience budget' from players because there's no financial commitment, which drives his focus on making tutorials and gameplay elements as clear and concise as possible.
context_findings.quote: With the romhack you have the disadvantage that no one paid for your game. So there's no initial commitment from the player. And because the N64 on 64x64 images can only have 16 colors. And transparency.

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes the game development process as a cycle that begins with fun and inevitably becomes torturous, noting that the completion rate for major romhacks is below 4%.
context_findings.quote: It always starts like really fun and eventually it turns into pure torture. That's just the cycle of making games.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is testing streaming on YouTube as an alternative to Twitch, expressing deep frustration with Twitch's aggressive ad policy, which he feels makes the platform unusable even for subscribers.
context_findings.quote: I tried to use Twitch all throughout like last week to personally watch streams and it is so ad-riddled that I just can't stand it anymore. So I decided, hey, let's test out YouTube.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is highly critical of the original Super Mario 64 engine, particularly its shadow system, which he considers extremely inefficient and easily fixable.
context_findings.quote: The Mario 64 object shadows are done so poorly. Like, if you are in Rainbow Ride and your game lags down to 25 FPS, a reasonably skilled programmer with like five minutes of time could have fixed the shadow system so that that runs at 30 FPS.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions that Nintendo previously took down one of his romhacks, 'Climate Change 64', and notes that his current project is 'technically illegal'.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided crucial design feedback for the tutorial, suggesting that players should have to pass through a ring to get a coin, preventing them from using unintended moves to complete the challenge.
During the stream, Biobak created and sent Kaze a new, improved texture for the tutorial UI prompt after seeing Kaze's placeholder version.
Biobak has done significant visual revamping on Course 1 to make it look prettier, including creating a new wood texture for the windmill.

zeina.summary: Zeina shared a work-in-progress animation of Bowser's hit reaction and provided critical feedback on it, noting that the pivot point was incorrect, which Kaze agreed with.
zeina.quote: It looks a little like he's not rotating around his actual middle. Like, he's flying backwards and then spinning and then flying forwards again.

zeina.summary: Kaze and Zeina's conversation reveals they live and work in close proximity, with Kaze's workout equipment located next to his development setup in their living space.

key_stories.title: Designing the Tutorial Ring Challenge
key_stories.summary: The team refined a flawed tutorial by moving from a simple coin collection to a more robust challenge involving passing through a ring with a specific move. This change, prompted by Biobak's feedback, ensures players actually learn the intended mechanic.
key_stories.challenge: The initial design for teaching players the dive jump was to have a bunny demonstrate it and then have the player collect a nearby coin. Kaze realized players could easily get the coin with a simple long jump, defeating the tutorial's purpose.
key_stories.process: After identifying the flaw, Kaze solicited feedback. Biobak suggested using a ring. Kaze agreed, then brainstormed ring designs, settling on a Yoshi's Island-inspired particle effect. He then coded the ring's appearance, the particle effects, and the logic to reward the player only for using the correct move.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented Biobak's suggestion. Now, after the bunny's demonstration, a particle-effect ring appears that the player must pass through using the correct move to receive the coin, ensuring the skill is properly learned.
key_stories.key_quote: My concern is that it's just gonna be a bit weird and confusing.

key_stories.title: Creating the Tutorial UI Prompt
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to create a clean UI prompt for tutorials due to technical limitations. In a moment of live collaboration, Biobak designed and delivered a much-improved asset, leading Kaze to delegate the task to him.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed a clear, visually appealing UI prompt to teach button combinations (e.g., Z then A) but struggled to create a good-looking texture within the N64's technical constraints, calling his own attempt 'crusty'.
key_stories.process: Kaze spent considerable time in Photoshop trying to create a speech bubble icon, fighting with scaling artifacts and color indexing. While he was working, Biobak independently created a superior version and sent it to him. Kaze, seeing the improvement, decided to use Biobak's work.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze delegated the final design of the tutorial prompts to Biobak, who had already created a much better version during the stream. This showcases their real-time, collaborative workflow.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh my god, this is one of the oldest things made. Look how shit this looks. Let's fix it.

key_stories.title: The Necessary Evil of a Forced Camera
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a fixed camera for a tutorial cutscene, forcing him to violate his own design principle of never wresting control from the player. He reluctantly implemented a 'dirty' hard-coded solution, showing a pragmatic trade-off between design purity and practical necessity.
key_stories.challenge: To ensure the player could see the bunny's demonstration, Kaze needed to force the game's camera into a fixed position, which violates his design rule of never taking camera control away from the player unexpectedly.
key_stories.process: Kaze first explained his philosophy on player-controlled cameras. He then searched the codebase for existing cutscene camera functions, finding one he called 'terrible'. After several failed attempts, he resorted to copying the 'dirty' code and hard-coding camera position values to get the desired shot.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a forced camera cutscene for the tutorial, but he was unhappy with the 'dirty' hard-coded solution. This illustrates the practical compromises sometimes required in game development, even when they go against a developer's own principles.
key_stories.key_quote: Well, it's kind of really fucking dirty. Well, it's terrible.
